thread.title: Lawmakers: Army Corps to clear obstacle to Dakota pipeline
thread.title_full: Lawmakers: Army Corps to clear obstacle to Dakota pipeline - POLITICO

author: Annie Snider
title: Lawmakers: Army Corps to clear obstacle to Dakota pipeline
text:
The Trump administration is preparing to remove a major obstacle for the Dakota Access oil pipeline, North Dakota lawmakers said Tuesday -- news that will reopen a fight with an American Indian tribe that has protested against the contentious energy project. In a statement , Rep. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.) said the Pentagon will notify Congress shortly that the Army Corps of Engineers is granting the easement needed to let the pipeline to cross below Lake Oahe. 
Story Continued Below
Sen. John Hoeven (R-N.D.) said in a separate statement that the acting Secretary of the Army "informed us that he has directed the Army Corps of Engineers to proceed with the easement needed to complete the Dakota Access Pipeline."
In December, the Obama administration put the easement on hold to allow for a more thorough environmental review and consultation with the Standing Rock Sioux, who have opposed the pipeline project which crosses Lake Oahe, their water supply, half a mile from the reservation. 

Trump picks Gorsuch for Supreme Court By Shane Goldmacher , Josh Gerstein and Matthew Nussbaum 
President Trump last week signed an order calling for the Army to swiftly "review and approve" all permits necessary for the $3.8 billion pipeline, which would ship as much as 570,000 barrels a day of oil from North Dakota fracking fields to Illinois refineries.
The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe vowed to fight in court if necessary, saying it would be premature and illegal for the Corps to approve the easement without finishing the necessary environmental review. "To abandon the [review] would amount to a wholly unexplained and arbitrary change based on the Presidentâ€™s personal views and, potentially, personal investments," the tribe said. "We stand ready to fight this battle against corporate interest superseding government procedure and the health and wellbeing of millions of Americans."
